li.a: GEAR UP at Marion City Schools
A Parent's Guide to Talking Career/College in Middle School
Why Work at Marion City Schools

li.a: Why Work at Marion City Schools

div.p: This page has been created specifically to help keep our students and families informed of news and updates regarding the District's closure due to the coronavirus, as well as to provide access to resources and the academic content that your child will need over the next three weeks to complete their assignments.

em.u: Click here to view K-12 Grading Information for Families

em.a: Click here to download the MCS Distance Learning Guide
Click here for help from the MCS Technology department
Click here to access the K-12 online learning dashboard
Click here to view the Step by Step Guide for the Student Landing Page
Click here to view information about internet access

em.u: Click here for the latest update from April 21, 2020

strong.em: Click here to view the MCS Frequently Asked Questions regarding the extended closure caused by COVID-19.

em.a: Click here to access the K-12 online learning dashboard
Click here for the Step by Step Guide for the Student Landing Page

strong.em: Click here to view the MCS Staff Contact List

u.a: Click here to view and download the Food Distribution information for MCS

ul.li: Meal distribution will be available Wednesdays throughout the extended closure. Parents or Guardians can now pick up the weekly meals for their children at the six locations on Wednesdays between 11 and 1pm.

Meal pick up locations include: Harding High School, Grant Middle School, George Washington Elementary, Hayes Elementary, McKinley Elementary and Taft Elementary. There is a limit of six meals per one adult. The meal program is only for children ages 1 to 18.

If you are in need of emergency personal hygiene products, a limited supply is available at the Grant Middle School location only on food distribution day. You can request a bag while picking up weekly meals. Again, supplies are very limited. Please reserve your request for an emergency situation only.

If you need further assistance for this emergency food for your children, please leave a message at 740-223-4423 or 740-223-4413 or email news@mcspresidents.org. Someone will be in contact with you as soon as possible. Please remember the meal distribution will take place on Wednesdays throughout the extended closure.

p.em: This institution is an equal opportunity provider.

div.p: The Ohio Department of Health has established a call center to answer your questions about this virus. Call center staff includes licensed nurses and infectious disease experts. They will be available to answer questions and provide accurate information about COVID-19, the risk to the public, and the state’s response.

1-833-4-ASK-ODH Open Seven Days a Week
Open 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m
OhioHealth has also published a COVID-19 Toolkit with information about testing, risks, symptoms, and more. Click here to view the OhioHealth toolkit.
The following list of links contains beneficial information for educators and the community about Coronavirus (COVID-19).

p.a: CDC – What to do if you are sick with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
CDC – What you need to know about coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
United States Dept. of Labor, Occupational Safety & Health Administration

ul.li: The Literacy Coaches of the Marion City Schools have put together a comprehensive list of the Free Little Libraries around Marion. These will be stocked with picture books and chapter books for students in grades K-5. Please feel free to visit these stops and "take a book and share a book"! Click here to see a list of Free Little Libraries.

em.u: Click here for information about internet access for students and families.

ul.li: FirstEnergy Corp. is committed to keeping the lights on through the coronavirus emergency. Effective immediately, the company's 10 electric utilities have taken action to maintain reliable service to customers by discontinuing power shut offs for customers who are past due on their electric bills. This action will also help limit in-person interactions between company employees and the public. FirstEnergy will continue to monitor the coronavirus response situation and adjust the shut off policy in the future as circumstances develop. residential customers who are facing a hardship due to the lack of income during this time should contact the company as soon as they are aware that paying their bill might become difficult. Options include budget billing, a program that averages usage over 12 months to offer the same bill amount each month, as well as energy assistance programs or other payment arrangements based on customers' situations and state of residence. Local customers can call 1-800-633-4766 for more information. (Information obtained from FirstEnergy Corp. website)
